training_organizations.name: Utah DCFS – Practice Improvement/Training
training_organizations.description: Utah’s Division of Child & Family Services partners with the University of Utah to train its CPS workforce and improve practice. DCFS has a Practice Improvement Team that develops curriculum and conducts training for new hires (for example, Utah’s New Employee Practice Model Training) and ongoing worker skill-building. Emphasis is placed on Utah’s Practice Model principles, such as engaging family teams and focusing on safety networks, and training is often scenario-based to reflect real cases.

training_organizations.name: Utah Foster Care
training_organizations.description: A unique nonprofit that contracts with the state to handle all foster family recruitment and training in Utah. Utah Foster Care finds prospective foster parents, runs the mandatory training courses for their licensure, and provides retention support (peer mentors, respite events) once they are approved. By outsourcing this function to an NGO, Utah DCFS ensures a consistent statewide approach to foster parent development and has significantly increased its pool of qualified foster families.

training_organizations.name: National Center on Substance Abuse and Child Welfare (NCSACW)
training_organizations.description: A federal technical assistance center that has worked with Utah on improving outcomes for families with substance use disorders. Through NCSACW’s involvement, Utah has implemented a specialized approach (e.g., family drug courts and the Utah Family Recovery, Engagement, and Empowerment Team model) to better integrate substance abuse treatment with child welfare case plans. This external support has helped DCFS staff receive training on engaging parents in treatment, understanding addiction, and partnering with treatment providers to ensure child safety.

perpetrator_relationships.relationship: Victim Was Child of Boyfriend or Girlfriend

policies.TribalFoster: Yes, Tribes within state provide foster care
policies.InvestQual_SW: Yes, recommended or preferred, but not required
policies.DefAge_Specify: Under age 18 and up to 21 if in the care of the agency
policies.ScreenerQual_SW: Yes, recommended or preferred, but not required
policies.Def_OtherSpecify: A child at risk of being neglected or abused because another child in the same home is neglected or abused; Dealing in material harmful to a child; That a child's natural parent: (1) intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly causes the death of another parent of the child, (2) is identified by a law enforcement agency as the primary suspect in an investigation for intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly causing the death of another parent of the child, or (3) is being prosecuted for or has been convicted of intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly causing the death of another parent of the child
policies.FatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.Def_Subtype_Abuse: Abuse includes sexual exploitation, sexual abuse, human trafficking, and that a child's natural parent : (1) intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly causes the death of another parent of the child, (2) is identified by a law enforcement agency as the primary suspect in an investigation for intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly causing the death of another parent of the child, or (3) is being prosecuted for or has been convicted of intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly causing the death of another parent of the child; Physical abuse may also include a child who suffered physical harm during a domestic violence episode
policies.CaseManagerQual_SW: Yes, recommended or preferred, but not required
policies.Def_Subtype_Neglect: Neglect includes abandonment (including an unregulated custody transfer), inability to meet parent responsibilities, medical neglect, educational neglect, environmental neglect, failure to protect, failure to thrive, non-supervision, and physical neglect (inadequate clothing, shelter, food, or other care necessary for the child's health, safety, morals, or well-being); A child at risk of being neglected or abused because another child in the same home is neglected or abused
policies.EquityStaff_Specify: Utah has American Indian/Alaska Native Health & Family Services administrators within the Department of Health and Human Services that work with the Division of Child and Family Services to improve outcomes for Indian citizens in Utah
policies.NearFatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.Penalty_OtherSpecify: The court may also order the individual to complete community service hours or complete a program on preventing abuse and neglect of children
policies.TribalFoster_Specify: Navajo Nation; Ute Indian Tribe of the Uintah and Ouray Reservation; Northwestern Band of the Shoshone Nation; Confederated Tribes of the Goshute Indian Reservations; Paiute Indian Tribe
policies.TribalScreen_Specify: Ute Indian Tribe of the Uintah and Ouray Reservation
policies.ReportInfo_OtherSpecify: Willingness of the referent to testify; Special circumstances or precautions recommended for investigation; Third-party/collateral contacts
policies.ScreenInfo_OtherSpecify: A query of Child and Family Services' Child Welfare Management Information System (SAFE) and Electronic Resource and Eligibility Product (EREP)
policies.DefAge_VaryByTypeSpecify: Some criminal justice statutes define a child differently for purposes of particular sexual offenses and in appropriate circumstances (unknown), those statutes may apply
policies.EquityStaff_OtherSpecify: The American Indian/Alaska Native Health & Family Services administrators work with the Division of Child and Family Services (DCFS) to improve outcomes for Indian citizens by developing policies and strategies that prioritize improving Indian health, facilitating working relationships between DCFS and tribal programs, and ensuring access to state programs for Indian citizens on or off the reservation
policies.DefPerp_VaryByTypeSpecify: Child's natural parent is the perpetrator when (1) intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly causes the death of another parent of the child, (2) identified by a law enforcement agency as the primary suspect in an investigation for intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly causing the death of another parent of the child, (3) being prosecuted for or has been convicted of intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly causing the death of another parent of the child; Perpetrators of sexual abuse are adults. A child is a perpetrator of sexual abuse if (1) there is an indication of force or coercion, (2) the children are related, including siblings by marriage while the marriage exists or by adoption, (3) there have been repeated incidents of sexual contact between the two children, unless the children are 14 years old or older, (4) there is a disparity in chronological age of four or more years between the two children; Perpetrators of education neglect are parents or guardians; Perpetrators of neglect are parents, guardians, or custodians
policies.InvestQual_TrainingSpecify: Core curriculum; On-the-job training that includes shadowing experienced child welfare caseworkers (required for caseworkers with less than 24 months of experience); Training on the application of risk assessment tools
policies.CentralizedReporting_Specify: Reports can be made to a peace officer, law enforcement agency, or office of the Division of Child and Family Services
policies.ScreenerQual_TrainingSpecify: Core curriculum; On-the-job training that includes shadowing experienced child welfare caseworkers (required for caseworkers with less than 24 months of experience); Training on the application of risk assessment tools
policies.InvestReq_MHEvalCases_Specify: Physical abuse; Sexual abuse; Medical neglect; Exposure to a hazardous, illegal chemical environment
policies.InvestReq_MedEvalCases_Specify: Physical abuse; Sexual abuse; Medical neglect; Exposure to a hazardous, illegal chemical environment
policies.NearFatalities_SpecificSpecify: A child who is certified by a physician to be in serious or critical condition and has been admitted to an Intensive Care Unit as a result of an injury or illness as a direct result of child abuse or neglect, excluding drug-exposed newborns who are admitted to a neonatal intensive care unit at the time of birth
policies.CaseManagerQual_TrainingSpecify: Core curriculum; On-the-job training that includes shadowing experienced child welfare caseworkers (required for caseworkers with less than 24 months of experience); Training on the application of risk assessment tools
policies.InvestReq_ReporterCases_Specify: Reports that were not made anonymously; Reports for which the third party/collateral contacts have had direct association with the child, or who are otherwise knowledgeable about the child's safety and family's functioning; Where possible and appropriate
policies.InvestReq_HomeVisitCases_Specify: If abuse was committed by a person who: is the child's parent, lives in the child's home, or has access to the child's home; If it is necessary to obtain evidence for the investigation
